clinical_study.official_title: Peer Support Dyads in a Health Promotion Program in African American Churches

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to explore how working with a partner can influence participation in a church wellness program. There are many different types of church wellness programs. Church members are more likely to participate and achieve goals in these programs when they have peer support. The researcher would like to know what African American men and women think about working with a support partner. This information will help researchers design better church wellness programs. The participants are being asked to take part in this research because the investigators believe that it is helpful to share feelings and thoughts about experiences working with a partner to achieve health goals. This knowledge will be used to create church wellness programs that will help African American men and women prevent disease and live healthier lives.

primary_outcome.measure: Feasibility as measured by a composite score of recruitment and retention
primary_outcome.description: Recruitment will be calculated from the number of churches who agree to participate divided by the total number who are contacted, and the number of members who consent to join the program divided by the total number of participants who come to the informational meeting. Retention will be calculated from the mean number of sessions participants attended out of the total number of sessions offered in Phase I and Phase II; the number of participants who continue to Phase II out of the number who complete Phase I (>50% attendance), and the attrition rate.

primary_outcome.measure: Participant perceptions of feasibility as measured by a composite score of survey, semi-structured interviews and log completion
primary_outcome.description: Ten item feasibility survey, scored based on 5-point Likert scale and a semi-structured post intervention participant interviews; Participant acceptability and feasibility of completing logs will be assessed by counting the number of logs submitted to the PI out of total number of program participants at weeks 14 and 18 (when logs should be submitted), and the number of logs actually completed.

primary_outcome.measure: Health educators' perceptions of feasibility as measured by semi-structured interviews

secondary_outcome.measure: Goal attainment as measured by changes in BMI
secondary_outcome.description: Paired t-tests will be used to assess changes in participant BMI pre and post intervention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Goal attainment as measured by changes in weight
secondary_outcome.description: Paired t-tests will be used to assess changes in participant weight pre and post intervention; A mixed model using intraclass correlation will be used to assess changes in weight at weeks 1, 9, 14, 18.

secondary_outcome.measure: Goal attainment as measured by changes in fruit and vegetable intake
secondary_outcome.description: Paired t-tests will be used to assess changes in participant fruit and vegetable intake pre and post intervention; A mixed model using intraclass correlation will be used to assess changes in fruit and vegetable intake at weeks 1, 9, and 18.

secondary_outcome.measure: Goal attainment as measured by changes in minutes of physical activity
secondary_outcome.description: Paired t-tests will be used to assess changes in participant physical activity pre and post intervention. A mixed model using intraclass correlation will be used to assess changes in physical activity at weeks 1, 9, and 18.

intervention.description: Phase I: At baseline and at post-intervention, participant height, weight, BMI, fruit and vegetable intake and exercise habits will be measured. Participants will complete surveys and meet each week to learn about nutrition and exercise. Phase II: Dyads will attend a communication training session to discuss 1) benefits of working with a partner; 2) supportive communication tips; and 3) expected activities for the next 8 weeks, including filling out daily logs. After the training session, the dyads will work together to achieve their health goals. The dyads will return to the church for two check in sessions. At these sessions, participants will turn in their logs, and be weighed. At the end of the intervention, BMI will be reassessed, and surveys and interviews will be completed.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The inclusion criteria will be churches with mostly African American members.
- Participant criteria will be: ages > 21 or older who identify as African American
- Attend church at least once per week
- Speak, read and write English
- Willing to complete study activities and assessments
- Able to engage in moderate physical activity. (e.g., walking - based on their own activity level and assessment).
